definitions.definition: a drawing or plan of the earth’s surface or part of it, showing countries, towns, rivers, etc.

examples.text: a map of France
a street map of Miami
a map of the area/region/world/route
to **read a/the map** *(= understand the information on a map)*
large-scale maps
Can you find Black Hill on the map?
to be marked/plotted/shown on a map
I'll draw you a map of how to get to my house.
Click here to download a map.
an interactive map
According to the map, we need to head north-east.
He followed the map to Red Square.
In 1924 the Soviet Union redrew the map of Central Asia.
Large maps were displayed around the meeting room.
Maps can reveal the history of a place.
Our town is just off the map.
The museum is clearly marked on the map.
We spread the map out on the floor.
A sketch map of the region showed the main mining areas.
Maria consulted the map.
The map isn't detailed enough to show individual streets.
The weather map showed storms approaching from the north.
There's a political map of Europe on page 28.
Tourist maps are on sale in most newsagents.
It displays the plane's location on a map.
a map of the stars

definitions.definition: a diagram to show the positions of things over an area

examples.text: an electron density map

definitions.definition: a diagram to show the position of genes on a chromosome

examples.text: a physical and genetic map of the entire human genome

definitions.definition: lacking organization; in a confused state

examples.text: Oil prices were all over the map last week, but they seem to be more stable now.
Although the town was completely off the map, I was glad that I made the effort to visit.

definitions.definition: to make somebody/something famous or important

examples.text: This chicken dish put the chef firmly on the map.
The exhibition has helped put the city on the map.

definitions.definition: to destroy or remove somebody/something completely

wordOrigin: early 16th cent.: from medieval Latin mappa mundi, literally ‘sheet of the world’, from Latin mappa ‘sheet, napkin’ + mundi ‘of the world’ (genitive of mundus).
